TLS must be used to protect and encrypt sensitive plaintext information in transit. It is recommended to use TLS for the end-to-end connection however TLS must implemented to secure the following:
• Authentication pages (before and after the user is authenticated)
• Once sensitive information are submitted before authentication (to ensure intruder cannot intercept and capture the sensitive details in plaintext)
Connection to the web application must not accept any connection via HTTP.

The main advantages of using strict-transport security header is to ensure that the browser does not communicate to the server over non-TLS connections. This helps reduce the risk of TLS stripping attacks as implemented by the sslsniff tool

Ensure masking of critical details such as PAN SSN Credit Card number etc. and ensure the details are encrypted in database. PCI DSS guidelines for credit/debit card related security controls should be implement where applicable.
When keys are stored in your system they must be properly secured and only accessible to the appropriate staff on a need to know basis.
Weak TLS ciphers must be disabled on all servers. For example SSL v2 has known weaknesses and is not considered to be secure. Additionally cryptographically weak ciphers and should not be used.

TLS certificates should be signed by a reputable certificate authority (“CA”). The name on the certificate should match the fully qualified domain name (“FQDN”) of the website. The certificate itself should be valid and not expired.

Cache control HTTP header should be disabled for the browser data caching within HTML page. In addition to that sensitive input fields should have autocomplete off. This control helps to avoid browser from capturing unnecessary credentials
Evaluation should be in place to ensure only required sensitive data is being transported or stored. It is recommended to use tokenization in order to reduce data exposure risks
The application shouldn't have any sensitive authentication credentials hardcoded into the source code.
Application should prompt for reconfirmation of the password if there are any changes to the detail of users.

Ensure a generic message is shown while resetting the password such as “You will receive a password reset email should the account exist” in place of a message such “The password reset link for your ID (johnsmith01) has been sent to you email”

note: This control is subject to business requirements.
Strong passwords protect systems from being hacked through brute force methods. Password length should be configured to be 8 characters or more.
All accounts should be locked indefinitely after 3 or less failed attempts and would only be unlocked by the administrator.

The connection between the processing layer (business logic tier) and database layer (data tier) of Web application must have authentication control. The credentials of business logic tier should be stored in centralized location and locked down.
The application and middleware must be configured to run with least privileges required to limit the impact in the event of a system compromise.
The application supports integration to directory service such as LDAP for user authentication.
The organization must be aware of MFA controls implemented by the provider to limit the chance of unauthorized access to the web application.

A user’s session must be closed after an inactive period of 15 or less minutes.

All output functions must contextually encode data before being sent to the user. 

note: This control helps to reduce the XSS attacks.

User input field should be validated on the input content. For security purposes whitelisting is preferable compare to blacklisting. This means that application should accept data that meets a certain criteria only.

In order to ensure the application is protected against SQL injection attacks SQL queries should pass user content into a bind variable. 

note: SQL queries should not be created dynamically using string concatenation. Similarly the SQL query string used in a bound or parameterized query should never be dynamically built from user input in order to ensure the application is protected against SQL injection attacks SQL queries should be made with user content passed into a bind variable.

This control helps to reduce the risk of CSRF (Cross-site request forgery) attacks by embedding a random value into HTML form.
The value of the random token should not be known to attacker.

It is advisable to use encoding for all pages containing HTTP headers or meta tags within HTML. Encoding must be consistent such as the use of UTF-8. This control helps to reduce the risk of Cross-site scripting attacks

If upload process is required for the Web application ensure the uploaded files are being validated in terms of size type contents as well as the file cannot override the destination path for the file. Below controls could be in place to avoid file upload attacks:
• Use a whitelist of allowed files
• Scan for Malware
• Randomize uploaded file names etc.

If user uploaded content is being hosted X-content-type-options should be used to help nosniff header that the browser does not try guessing the data type. 
note: Ensure server or application determines the data type

The source of the input must be validated before processing. For example if input is expected from a POST request do not accept the input variables from GET request. Ensure that the application should access only allowed HTTP Methods and prevent disallowed ones such as change of GET to POST PUT to DELETE etc.

Application should avoid copying user-controllable data into HTTP response headers or else data should be strictly validated to prevent response header injection attacks. Failing to prevent this could also lead to cross-site scripting attacks.
X-Frame options header helps to prevent the content from being loaded by a foreign site in a frame such as <frame> <iframe> <embed> or <object>. This control reduces the risk of clickjacking attacks

Content Security Policy (CSP) and X-XSS-Protection headers help to protect the application from common Cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks
*Content Security Policy (CSP) which is defined by W3C Specs as standard header refer to https://www.w3.org/TR/CSP1/ for more information.

comment: User requirements phase: security risk assessment has been carried out starting before the system is designed (eg threat modeling). Development phase: System Development Environment (SDE) is separate from the production & testing environment. Development phase: Access is provided in accordance with IAM Best practices where segregation of duty and least privileges principles are implemented for development users who require access to the production environment. Development phase: Security checks are carried out both automatically (code scanning) and manually during the system development phase. Development phase: Restricted access for use of public source code repositories (e.g. : GitHub and GitLab) Testing phase: Unit test; system integration tests and stress tests/load tests must be carried out before the User Acceptance Test (UAT). Testing phase: Production data (especially containing confidential information) is not used for testing purposes unless sanitized. Deployment phase: Security testing on the application before going live and when changes are made.
